text: charring vegetables has become a pretty
cool Chevy thing to do and no one nails
it like chef Christian policie from
relay in Manfred's in Copenhagen his
technique will turn this humble cabbage
into something pretty awesome so this is
just a plain green cabbage you're going
to start by cutting it in half straight
through the core just a little bit of
oil any neutral oil grape seed canola
just enough to coat the bottom of the
pan and I'm over about medium-high heat
it's going right into the pan cut side
down I'll just move it around at the
beginning to make sure oil gets on the
flat side but after that I'm really not
going to touch this cabbage again for
about 10 or 15 minutes we're basically
taking this to the very edge of burning
if you think you've gone too far that's
actually when you're doing it right so
this cabbage has been going for a while
I want to show you what it looks like
it's pretty much black in the center and
it's going out to a really dark nice
brown on the edge this is what I'm going
to start the second stage of this
cooking which basically involves a big
back of butter when the butter gets in
there it's gonna start foaming right
away this is brown butter it smells
awesome you just want to tilt your pan
so that the butter is cooling and start
spooning that over the cabbage it's
gonna heat it up it's gonna drench it
with delicious buttery flavor and it's
also gonna start to cook it make sure as
you're going you get dark brown hot
butter onto the fore side as well that's
the densest part of the vegetable and
you want to make sure that this is
tender everywhere if it seems like it's
getting just a little bit too dark if
you're seeing mostly black flecks in the
butter you can always add softened
butter to the pan it's gonna cool down
the butter that's already in there and
kind of bring it back from the brink
after you've been going for about half a
minute just gonna let it hang out
three minutes the next ingredient is a
little bit of kelp powder you're gonna
go to the supermarket and just look for
dried konbu or kelp break it up into a
couple of pieces and these are going
into a spice mill and in the end you
have this seaweed flavor
powder I'm gonna add the konbu right
into the brown butter and we're just
gonna base that over for the very last
stage of the cooking I feel really good
about this cabbage right now I can tell
the top is like browned and really
tender to check it I'm going to use a
cake tester not just for cake people so
for this we're gonna go in a spot near
the core that you know is the thickest
densest place you'll sort of feel it
pass through individual layers it is
super tender I think we're done
so now carefully with a pair of tongs
bring the cabbage over to my cutting
board just any little too dry pieces are
gonna come off so now we're going to cut
it in half into quarters so just lining
your knife up with the core right
through super tender you have this
pretty awesome black and white half
charred
half tender inside of the cabbage and
now we haven't seasoned the cabbage at
all take a little bit of salt get in
between those layers so it's seasoned
everywhere and then I love this part you
want to take a little bit of fresh basil
tuck it in between some of these layers
and the heat of the cabbage right away
starts to warm up and the smell of the
basil comes right out then it just adds
a little green fresh aromatic hit at the
end
and this very last little bit of
seasoning is a little bit of vinegar I'm
using cider vinegar just a few drops I
promise this dish will forever change
the way you think about cabbage but will
also give you the courage to burn things
more often in your kitchen and make it
look good for more pro recipes and chef
tips like this one go to Bon Apetit calm
slash clap just like back
